content.heading: History
paragraphs: C++ is a general-purpose programming language that was developed as an extension of the C language. It introduced object-oriented programming features while maintaining the efficiency and flexibility of C.

content.heading: Origin and Development
paragraphs: C++ was created by Bjarne Stroustrup in 1979 at Bell Labs. Initially, it was known as 'C with Classes' because it added object-oriented programming features to C.
The first official version of C++ was released in 1983. It introduced features such as classes, objects, and operator overloading.

content.heading: Standardization and Evolution
paragraphs: C++ continued to evolve with various standard versions. The first standard, C++98, was published in 1998, bringing stability to the language.
Subsequent updates like C++03, C++11, C++14, C++17, and C++20 introduced improvements such as smart pointers, lambda functions, and parallel programming support.

content.heading: Key Features Introduced Over Time
paragraphs: C++98 (1998) - The first standardized version of C++, focusing on stability.
C++11 (2011) - Introduced modern features like auto keyword, lambda expressions, and smart pointers.
C++14 (2014) - Minor updates and improvements over C++11.
C++17 (2017) - Introduced features like structured bindings and filesystem library.
C++20 (2020) - Added concepts, ranges, coroutines, and modules for better code organization.

content.heading: Current and Future Trends
paragraphs: C++ remains a popular language for systems programming, game development, and high-performance applications.
With ongoing development, future versions of C++ are expected to bring more safety features and further improvements in performance.
